curriculumTitle: Future Ready: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence for Texas High Schoolers
overview: A comprehensive 20-module curriculum designed for TRIO Upward Bound and UBMS programs in Texas. This curriculum breaks down AI fundamentals, ethics, coding concepts, and career planning into standalone 30-minute lessons. It moves from basic definitions to technical mechanics, creative applications, and finally career readiness.
prerequisites: Students should have basic computer literacy (typing, internet navigation) and a reading level appropriate for 9th grade. No prior coding experience is required.

fieldTrips.name: Perot Museum of Nature and Science - Engineering and Innovation Hall
fieldTrips.description: Exploration of the Engineering Hall focusing on the 'Robot Arena' and automated systems exhibits to visualize hardware components of AI.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Provides physical context to the 'Robotics vs. AI' concepts discussed in Module 15. Connects abstract code to physical movement.

fieldTrips.name: University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) Research Institute
fieldTrips.description: Tour of the automation and robotics research labs at UTARI.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Demonstrates collegiate pathways in STEM and exposes students to advanced research environments (UBMS Component).

fieldTrips.name: Richardson IQ (Innovation Quarter)
fieldTrips.description: Visit to 'The IQ' headquarters to observe startups utilizing machine learning in real-time business applications.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Connects 'Future of AI' concepts to the local North Texas economic landscape and entrepreneurship.

fieldTrips.name: Fort Worth Museum of Science and History
fieldTrips.description: Interaction with the Energy Blast exhibit to understand smart grid technology and data analysis in the energy sector.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Illustrates the intersection of data science (AI) and the Texas energy sector.

fieldTrips.name: Dallas College (Richland Campus) - Computer Science Dept
fieldTrips.description: Campus tour focusing on the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Associate Degree pathways.
fieldTrips.relevanceToCurriculum: Direct connection to 'College Pathways' and exposure to post-secondary education requirements (HEA Requirement).

activities.title: Module 1: The Hierarchy of Intelligence (AI vs. ML vs. DL)
activities.description: An introductory lesson defining the relationship between Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning using concentric circle visualization.
learningObjectives: Define Artificial Intelligence as the umbrella term for smart machines.
Differentiate between Machine Learning (learning from data) and Deep Learning (neural networks).
Classify common apps (Netflix, Siri) into the AI hierarchy.
teks: 126.33 (c)(1)(A) - Computer Science I: Identify and define the problem to be solved.
130.402 (c)(2)(D) - STEM: Describe the history and evolution of technology.
texasStemStandards: STEM Sub-Chapter A: Inquiry and Design
STEM Sub-Chapter C: Technology Operations and Concepts

materialsList.item: Printed Handouts: 'The AI Nesting Dolls' diagram

brief: 1. Hook: Ask who uses TikTok. Explain that the 'algorithm' is AI.
2. Instruction: Draw three concentric circles (AI > ML > DL).
3. Analogy: AI is the Car, ML is the Engine, Data is the Fuel.
4. Activity: Students categorize different technologies into the circles.
detailed: Step 1: Introduction (5 mins) - Start with 'Is a calculator AI?' (No). 'Is Alexa AI?' (Yes).
Step 2: The Hierarchy (10 mins) - Draw circles. AI (Outer), ML (Middle), DL (Inner).
Step 3: Analogy (5 mins) - Use the 'Vehicle' analogy. AI is transportation, ML is the engine, Data is gas.
Step 4: Check for Understanding (10 mins) - Sticky note activity sorting terms like Self-driving car vs Excel.

brief: 1. Participate in the 'Calculator vs. Alexa' debate.
2. Draw the AI/ML/DL diagram in your notes.
3. Sort technology cards into the correct category.
detailed: 1. Discussion: Why do we call it 'Artificial'?
2. Visualization: Create the diagram. Label AI, ML, DL.
3. Application: Where does ChatGPT fit? (Deep Learning).
4. Reflection: Explain why all Deep Learning is AI, but not all AI is Deep Learning.

trioCompliance.justification: This activity provides foundational scientific literacy required for STEM careers, directly supporting the UBMS core science curriculum mandate.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Academic instruction in mathematics and science
cfrCitations: 34 CFR 645.11(a)(1) - Academic instruction in core subjects

activities.title: Module 2: A Brief History of Minds (Turing to Transformers)
activities.description: A timeline exploration of AI history, focusing on the Turing Test and the evolution from rules-based systems to modern generative AI.
learningObjectives: Explain the 'Turing Test' and its significance.
Recognize the shift from 'Expert Systems' to 'Neural Networks'.
teks: 113.41 (c)(27)(C) - US History: Impact of tech innovations.
texasStemStandards: STEM Sub-Chapter A: Inquiry and Design

detailed: Step 1: The Turing Test (10 mins) - Can a machine fool a human? Play a chat game.
Step 2: Timeline (15 mins) - Highlight key milestones (Deep Blue vs Kasparov, AlphaGo).
Step 3: Reflection (5 mins) - Are we in an AI Spring?

brief: 3. Discuss if current AI passes the Turing Test.
detailed: 1. Listen to the chat transcript read aloud. Guess if it's human or bot.
2. Mark the 'AI Winters' on your timeline.
3. Write down one invention that changed AI history.

trioCompliance.justification: Historical context is essential for scientific literacy.
heaRequirements: HEA Sec. 402C(b) - Instruction in core subjects

activities.title: Module 3: Algorithms (The Recipe for Intelligence)
activities.description: Demystifying algorithms by creating physical flowcharts and 'programming' a teacher to make a sandwich.
learningObjectives: Define 'Algorithm' as a step-by-step set of instructions.
Understand the importance of precision in coding.
Create a flowchart for a daily task.

brief: 2. Activity: Students write instructions to make a PB&J.
detailed: Step 1: The Challenge (5 mins) - Tell students to write instructions.
Step 2: Execution (15 mins) - If they say 'put peanut butter on bread', put the jar on the loaf. Force them to debug.
Step 3: Flowchart (10 mins) - Translate corrected steps to a visual map.

brief: 1. Write steps to make a sandwich.
detailed: 1. Be specific. 'Open jar' is step 1.
2. Fix bugs in your code (instructions).
3. Use diamond shapes for decisions (Is jar open? Yes/No).

trioCompliance.justification: Fundamental logic and algorithmic thinking.

activities.title: Module 4: Data - The Fuel for AI
activities.description: Understanding the difference between Structured (Excel) and Unstructured (Images/Text) data and how machines consume it.
learningObjectives: Differentiate between Structured and Unstructured data.
Understand why AI needs massive datasets.

brief: 1. Analogy: Engine needs gas; AI needs data.
detailed: Step 1: Types of Data (10 mins) - Define Structured vs Unstructured.
Step 2: The Labeling Problem (15 mins) - Give students raw photos. Ask them to create a spreadsheet describing them. Show how hard it is.
Step 3: Wrap (5 mins) - Why Google has an advantage (Data supremacy).

brief: 1. Look at the spreadsheet vs. the photo album.
2. Try to convert the photos into a table.
3. Discuss which is harder for a computer to read.
detailed: 1. Categorize list of items as Structured or Unstructured.
2. 'Tag' a set of images (create metadata).
3. Explain why ChatGPT needed the whole internet to learn.

trioCompliance.justification: Data literacy is a core component of modern STEM.

activities.title: Module 5: The Neural Network Game (Kinesthetic Learning)
activities.description: A physical activity where students act out the roles of neurons in a network to understand how computers 'learn' through weights and biases.
learningObjectives: Model a simple neural network structure (Input -> Hidden Layer -> Output).
Demonstrate how 'weights' determine if a neuron fires.
Understand the concept of 'Training' via error correction.
texasStemStandards: STEM Sub-Chapter A: Creativity and Innovation

brief: 2. Input passes tokens based on picture.
3. Hidden sums tokens; fires if > threshold.
4. Output predicts. 5. Adjust rules if wrong.
detailed: Step 1: Setup (5 mins) - Create network with string.
Step 2: Forward Pass (10 mins) - Input nodes fire if pixel is colored. Hidden nodes sum inputs.
Step 3: Error (5 mins) - Compare output to reality.
Step 4: Backprop (10 mins) - Change thresholds to fix error.
1. Roleplay a neuron.
2. Sum inputs. Compare to Threshold.
3. Fire (pass token) if Sum > Threshold.
4. Backpropagate: Change threshold if teacher says 'Wrong'.

trioCompliance.justification: Rigorous math/science instruction through physical modeling.

activities.title: Module 6: How LLMs Think (Next Token Prediction)
activities.description: An interactive lab de-mystifying Large Language Models by explaining the probability math behind 'Next Token Prediction'.

brief: 3. Lab: Students use AI to finish sentences with low probability.
detailed: Step 1: Theory (5 mins) - Tokenization.
Step 2: Prediction Game (5 mins) - Predict next word based on probability.
Step 3: Hallucination (10 mins) - Ask impossible questions.
Step 4: Activity (10 mins) - Generate stories word by word.
1. Open AI.
2. Experiment with 'The sky is green because...'.
3. Understand AI isn't thinking, just calculating.
4. Generate fake bio.

trioCompliance.justification: Links English composition with technology.

activities.title: Module 7: Prompt Engineering 101 (The RTFC Framework)
activities.description: Workshop on controlling AI outputs using Role, Task, Format, Constraint.

detailed: Step 1: Bad Prompt (5 mins).
Step 2: RTFC Formula (10 mins).
Step 3: Application (10 mins) - Generate study guide.
Step 4: Refinement (5 mins).
1. Practice Few-Shot prompting.
2. Apply RTFC to homework help.
3. Submit best prompt.

trioCompliance.justification: Teaches technology as a study aid.

activities.title: Module 8: Computer Vision (How Machines 'See')
activities.description: Breaking down images into pixels and RGB numbers to understand computer vision.
learningObjectives: Explain that images are grids of numbers (Pixels).
Simulate a computer reading a handwritten number.

brief: 3. Activity: Students turn a number grid into a drawing.
detailed: Step 1: Pixels (5 mins) - Zoom in on a photo.
Step 2: The Grid (10 mins) - Explain how 0 is black and 255 is white.
Step 3: Color by Number (10 mins) - Give a grid of numbers; students color it.
Step 4: Application (5 mins) - Self-driving cars seeing lane lines.

brief: 2. Shade squares based on the number value.
detailed: 1. Treat the grid like a bitmap.
2. 0 = Black, 1 = White (or RGB codes).
3. Recognize that computers don't see 'cat', they see matrix math.

trioCompliance.justification: Mathematical representation of visual data.

activities.title: Module 9: Supervised vs. Unsupervised Learning
activities.description: A card-sorting game to distinguish between learning with an answer key (Supervised) and finding patterns alone (Unsupervised).
learningObjectives: Apply concepts to real-world scenarios (Spam filters vs. Customer segmentation).

materialsList.item: Deck of Cards or Image Set

brief: 4. Activity 2: Cluster alien shapes without labels.
detailed: Step 1: Definitions (10 mins).
Step 2: Supervised Game (5 mins) - Sort into buckets labeled 'Apple'/'Banana'.
Step 3: Unsupervised Game (10 mins) - Give weird shapes. Ask students to group them. There is no 'right' answer, just patterns.
Step 4: Application (5 mins) - Netflix recommendations (Unsupervised clustering).

brief: 2. Sort strange items into piles based on similarities.
detailed: 1. Experience 'Training' a model.
2. Realize Unsupervised learning is about finding hidden structures.
3. Explain why Unsupervised is harder.

trioCompliance.justification: Foundational statistics and CS logic.

activities.title: Module 10: Generative Art (Diffusion Models)
activities.description: Exploration of how AI creates images from noise, using tools like Bing Image Creator or Stable Diffusion.
learningObjectives: Discuss copyright issues in AI art.

brief: 1. Explain Diffusion: Turning static into a picture.
3. Activity: Prompting for specific art styles.
4. Ethics Chat: Is it stealing from artists?
detailed: Step 1: The Fog Analogy (5 mins) - Imagine looking at clouds until you see a shape.
Step 2: Lab (15 mins) - Generate images. Try 'Oil Painting' vs 'Photorealistic'.
Step 3: Ethics (10 mins) - Who owns the image?

brief: 1. Write a prompt describing a scene.
detailed: 1. Use the tool to create a logo for a fake company.
2. Experiment with negative prompts (what NOT to include).
3. Debate: Should artists be paid if AI trains on their work?

trioCompliance.justification: Connects Arts and STEM (STEAM).

activities.title: Module 11: Algorithmic Bias (Garbage In, Garbage Out)
activities.description: Critical thinking session examining how AI inherits prejudices from human data, focusing on facial recognition.
learningObjectives: Identify sources of bias in training data.

detailed: Step 1: Bucket Analogy (5 mins).
Step 2: Real World Impact (10 mins) - Facial recognition failure rates.
Step 3: Discussion (10 mins) - Redlining via algorithms.
Step 4: Closing (5 mins) - Algorithmic Justice.
1. Count demographics in training set.
2. Discuss fixes (better data).
3. Reflection on Ethics in STEM.

trioCompliance.justification: Aligns with HEA requirements for critical thinking and civics.

activities.title: Module 12: Deepfakes & Media Literacy
activities.description: Learning to detect synthetic media and understanding the implications of 'Deepfakes' for society.
learningObjectives: Identify visual artifacts in fake videos.
Discuss the impact on news and trust.

brief: 1. Show a Deepfake of a celebrity.
detailed: Step 1: The Hook (5 mins) - Is this Tom Cruise?
Step 2: The Tech (10 mins) - Explain Generative Adversarial Networks.
Step 3: Detective Work (10 mins) - Look for blinking, lip sync, earlobes.
Step 4: Ethics (5 mins) - Misinformation.
1. Examine the 'Uncanny Valley'.
2. Learn about 'Watermarking' content.
3. Pledge to verify sources before sharing.

trioCompliance.justification: Media literacy is crucial for college readiness.

activities.title: Module 13: AI in Healthcare (Diagnosis Detective)
activities.description: Simulation of how AI assists doctors in detecting patterns in medical imaging like X-Rays.
learningObjectives: Compare human accuracy vs AI accuracy.
Discuss the 'Human in the Loop' necessity.

detailed: Step 1: Training (5 mins) - Show what pneumonia looks like (cloudy lungs).
Step 2: Diagnosis (10 mins) - Students race to label images.
Step 3: AI comparison (5 mins) - Explain AI does this in seconds.
Step 4: Ethics (10 mins) - Who is liable if AI is wrong?

brief: 5. Discuss if you'd trust a robot doctor.
detailed: 1. Experience fatigue (getting tired after 10 images).
2. Understand AI doesn't get tired.
3. Conclude that Doctor + AI is best.

trioCompliance.justification: Direct link to medical careers and biology.

activities.title: Module 14: NLP & Sentiment Analysis
activities.description: Teaching computers to understand emotion by assigning numerical values to positive and negative words.
learningObjectives: Understand how brands use this to monitor social media.

detailed: Step 1: The Math of Feelings (5 mins).
Step 2: Scoring (10 mins) - 'The food was good (+1) but service was bad (-1)' = 0 (Neutral).
Step 3: Sarcasm (10 mins) - 'Great, another flat tire.' AI sees 'Great' (+2). Discuss context.
Step 4: Application (5 mins) - Stock market analysis.

brief: 3. Try to trick the system with sarcasm.
detailed: 1. Convert text to numbers.
2. Identify limitations of simple keyword matching.
3. Realize importance of context.

trioCompliance.justification: Interdisciplinary Math/English activity.

activities.title: Module 15: Robotics vs. AI (Body vs. Brain)
activities.description: Distinguishing between the physical machine (Robot) and the software intelligence (AI) using sensors and actuators concepts.
learningObjectives: Design a hypothetical robot for a specific task.

brief: 1. Clarify: A remote control car is a robot, but not AI.
detailed: Step 1: Definitions (5 mins) - AI is the pilot; Robot is the plane.
Step 2: Anatomy (10 mins) - Input/Process/Output loop.
Step 3: Design Challenge (10 mins) - Draw a robot. What sensors does it need? Camera? Lidar?
Step 4: Review (5 mins).

brief: 1. List differences between RC car and Self-driving car.
detailed: 1. Understand hardware limitations.
2. Apply logic: If sensor sees trash, actuator grabs it.
3. Discuss automation.

trioCompliance.justification: Core engineering concepts.

activities.title: Module 16: Future of Work (Automation vs. Augmentation)
activities.description: Career exploration distinguishing between jobs replaced by AI vs. jobs enhanced by AI.

brief: 3. Activity: Look up dream job on O*NET.
detailed: Step 1: Reality Check (5 mins).
Step 2: Research (10 mins) - O*NET OnLine.
Step 3: Analysis (10 mins) - T-Chart of tasks.
Step 4: Closing (5 mins) - Identify skills to learn.

brief: 3. Create T-Chart: AI Tasks vs Human Tasks.
detailed: 1. Imagine 2035.
2. 'My Day as an AI-Assisted [Job]'.
3. Share description.

trioCompliance.justification: Primary TRIO mandate: informed career choices.

activities.title: Module 17: Ethics - The Trolley Problem 2.0
activities.description: Applying moral philosophy to autonomous vehicle programming decisions.
learningObjectives: Discuss how to program ethics into cars.

brief: 2. Update for Self-Driving Cars (Save passenger vs Save pedestrian).
detailed: Step 1: The Dilemma (5 mins).
Step 2: Scenarios (15 mins) - Present variations (Jaywalkers, animals, etc.).
Step 3: Programming (10 mins) - Explain that engineers must write this code ahead of time.

brief: 4. Discuss: Should you be able to buy a car that prioritizes YOU?
detailed: 1. Put yourself in the engineer's shoes.
2. Write a policy for a car company.
3. Debate with classmates.

trioCompliance.justification: Critical thinking and civic engagement.

activities.title: Module 18: Capstone Prep - Identifying a Problem
activities.description: Brainstorming session using Design Thinking to identify a local community problem solvable with AI.
learningObjectives: Apply the 'Empathize' stage of Design Thinking.
Identify a local issue (e.g., Traffic, Recycling).

detailed: Step 1: Empathy (5 mins) - What bugs you about your city?
Step 2: Ideation (15 mins) - Sticky note storm.
Step 3: Selection (10 mins) - Pick one feasible problem.

brief: 3. Ask: Is this a data problem?
detailed: 1. Focus on 'pain points'.
2. Don't solve it yet, just define it.
3. Example: 'How might we use camera AI to speed up the lunch line?'

trioCompliance.justification: Research project initiation.

activities.title: Module 19: Capstone Project - Paper Prototyping
activities.description: Creating a low-fidelity paper prototype of an AI application interface.
learningObjectives: Explain where the AI 'magic' happens in the app.

brief: 1. Explain Prototyping (Fake it 'til you make it).
3. Simulation: One student presses 'buttons', another swaps papers.
detailed: Step 1: UI Basics (5 mins).
Step 2: Drafting (15 mins) - Draw Main Menu, Camera View, Results Screen.
Step 3: User Flow (10 mins) - Walk through the usage.

brief: 1. Draw your app screens on paper.
4. Explain: 'When I click this, the AI recognizes the face.'
detailed: 1. Visualize the input and output.
2. Don't worry about artistic skill, worry about flow.
3. Annotate: Label the AI function.

trioCompliance.justification: Engineering design process.

activities.title: Module 20: Pitch Perfect (Presenting AI Ideas)
activities.description: Final presentation workshop teaching students how to communicate technical ideas to non-technical audiences.
learningObjectives: Translate technical jargon into plain English.

detailed: Step 1: Structure (5 mins).
Step 2: Drafting (10 mins) - Write the script.
Step 3: Rehearsal (10 mins) - Practice with partner.
Step 4: Presentation (5 mins) - Select a few to share.

brief: 1. Answer: What is it? How does it use AI? Why does it matter?
detailed: 1. Avoid buzzwords without explanation.
2. Focus on the human benefit.
3. Sell the idea!

trioCompliance.justification: Soft skills are essential for college success.
